questions.text: A structure in the nasopharynx is marked. Identify the structure.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Torus tubarius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The torus tubarius is an elevation in the nasopharynx formed by the cartilage of the Eustachian tube and is a key anatomical landmark in the region.
  • ➤ torus tubarius

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of right-sided ear pain for the past two weeks. He denies any hearing loss, discharge from the ear, or history of trauma. Otoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane and external auditory canal. However, he reports a sore throat and difficulty swallowing. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tonsillitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Referred otalgia in the absence of positive ear findings may result from irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve , as seen in conditions like tonsillitis.
  • ➤ glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with chronic ear pain. Upon examination, the tympanic membrane appears normal. Considering the nerve supply of the tympanic membrane (TM), which nerve is likely involved if the pain is localized to the outer anterior half of the TM?

options.label: B
options.text: Arnold’s nerve (auricular branch of the vagus nerve)

options.label: C
options.text: Jacobson’s nerve (tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve)

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Auriculotemporal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The auriculotemporal nerve supplies the outer anterior half of the tympanic membrane, while Arnold’s nerve (vagus) supplies the posterior half and Jacobson’s nerve (glossopharyngeal) supplies the inner surface.
  • ➤ auriculotemporal nerve

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent ear infections and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida. Which of the following anatomical areas is most likely involved in the formation of a cholesteatoma in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prussak space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prussak space is the primary site involved in the formation of cholesteatomas, particularly those arising from retraction pockets in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane.
  • ➤ Prussak space

questions.text: A surgeon is preparing to perform a mastoidectomy and needs to locate the mastoid antrum. Which of the following landmarks is used to identify the position of the antrum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MacEwen’s triangle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MacEwen’s triangle is the landmark used to locate the mastoid antrum during mastoidectomy. It is bounded by the temporal line, the posterior wall of the external auditory canal, and a tangent drawn along the posterior mastoid.
  • ➤ MacEwen’s triangle

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss. She reports hearing better in noisy environments. Otoscopic examination reveals an intact tympanic membrane with a reddish hue over the promontory. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve (Carhart’s notch). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otosclerosis is characterized by progressive conductive hearing loss, often with paracusis Willisii, Schwartze’s sign, and Carhart’s notch on audiometry.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a history of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Otoscopic examination reveals a red reflex behind an intact tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glomus tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A glomus tumor is a vascular middle ear tumor that presents with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss, and a red reflex behind an intact tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and chronic heart failure is prescribed furosemide. He later develops hearing impairment. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of his hearing loss?

options.label: B
options.text: Oedema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis

options.label: C
options.text: Vasoconstriction of small vessels in the cochlea

questions.correct_answer: B. Oedema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oedema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Furosemide causes hearing loss by inducing edema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis, which impairs endolymph production and disrupts the ionic gradient necessary for normal cochlear function.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoing chemotherapy for cancer presents with hearing impairment. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cisplatin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cisplatin is a chemotherapeutic agent that causes dose-dependent, irreversible sensorineural hearing loss by damaging cochlear hair cells.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with episodes of vertigo that occur when she turns her head quickly. The episodes last for a few seconds and are associated with nausea. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver is positive. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) presents with short episodes of vertigo triggered by positional changes and is diagnosed using the Dix-Hallpike maneuver.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with episodes of vertigo that occur when she moves her head quickly. The episodes last for a few seconds and are accompanied by nausea. Which structure in the inner ear is primarily responsible for sensing the angular movements that lead to her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cristae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cristae ampullaris within the semicircular canals are responsible for detecting angular or rotational head movements, distinguishing them from the maculae in the otolith organs, which detect linear acceleration.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, aural fullness, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus. She is diagnosed with Meniere's disease. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism?

options.label: C
options.text: Excessive endolymph in the inner ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Excessive endolymph in the inner ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Excessive endolymph in the inner ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meniere's disease is caused by endolymphatic hydrops, where excessive endolymph in the inner ear disrupts auditory and vestibular function, resulting in vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and aural fullness.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman experiences sudden onset vertigo and hearing loss. Imaging reveals a mass within the internal auditory canal (IAC). Which structure is most likely affected if the mass is located in the anterosuperior part of the IAC?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Facial nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve occupies the anterosuperior quadrant of the internal auditory canal (IAC). A mass in this region is most likely to affect the facial nerve, potentially causing facial motor symptoms.
  • ➤ facial nerve

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with gradually increasing unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. MRI with gadolinium contrast reveals a mass in the cerebellopontine angle. Which cranial nerve is most likely the initial origin of this tumor?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inferior vestibular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) most commonly originate from the inferior vestibular nerve and present with gradual unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and a mass in the cerebellopontine angle.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of otitis media. Which of the following anatomical differences between the Eustachian tube in infants and adults most likely contributes to the increased risk of otitis media in infants?

options.label: D
options.text: Shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube in infants

questions.correct_answer: D. Shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube in infants
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube in infants

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infants are at an increased risk for otitis media due to their shorter, more horizontal Eustachian tubes, which facilitate the spread of infections from the nasopharynx to the middle ear.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with ear pain, fever, and a feeling of ear fullness. Otoscopic examination reveals a congested tympanic membrane with a cartwheel appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Acute otitis media in the presuppuration stage

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute otitis media in the presuppuration stage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute otitis media in the presuppuration stage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cartwheel appearance of the tympanic membrane is a hallmark of the presuppuration stage of acute otitis media, which presents with fever, ear pain, and a sensation of ear fullness.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent ear infections and persistent discharge from the right ear. Otoscopic examination reveals a retraction pocket in the pars flaccida and a pearly white mass behind the tympanic membrane. Which theory of cholesteatoma formation is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory explains the formation of primary acquired cholesteatoma due to Eustachian tube dysfunction and progressive tympanic membrane retraction.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a whitish mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, noted during a routine school screening. She has no history of ear infections or ear trauma. Which type of cholesteatoma is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital cholesteatoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital cholesteatomas are typically asymptomatic and are incidentally identified during examinations as a whitish mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, with no history of ear infections or trauma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a long-standing history of ear discharge and hearing loss. Examination reveals a central perforation of the tympanic membrane with profuse, mucoid discharge that is non-foul-smelling and non-blood-stained. Which type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tubotympanic type

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubotympanic CSOM is a "safe type" of chronic otitis media, characterized by central perforation of the tympanic membrane and profuse, non-foul-smelling discharge, with a lower risk of complications compared to the unsafe type.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic suppurative otitis media undergoes mastoid surgery. Postoperatively, he is advised that he will need routine cleaning of his ear by a doctor once or twice a year. Which type of mastoidectomy did he most likely undergo?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Canal-wall-down mastoidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A canal-wall-down mastoidectomy creates an open cavity that disrupts epithelial migration, necessitating lifelong regular cleaning to prevent debris accumulation and infection. Patients must avoid activities like swimming to prevent water-induced complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents for tympanoplasty. During the surgery, the surgeon finds that both the malleus and incus are absent. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Type III tympanoplasty, the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent, as per Wullstein’s classification.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of ear pain, fever, and purulent ear discharge. Examination reveals a smooth and shiny appearance of the mastoid surface, tenderness over the mastoid area, and a sagging posterior meatal wall. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mastoiditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mastoiditis is characterized by mastoid tenderness, smooth and shiny mastoid surface, sagging posterior meatal wall, and systemic signs of infection. It is a complication of acute otitis media requiring prompt management.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with deep-seated retro-orbital pain, diplopia, and persistent ear discharge. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Petrositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gradenigo’s triad (retro-orbital pain, diplopia, and persistent ear discharge) is a hallmark of petrositis, a rare complication of chronic otitis media that involves infection of the petrous apex of the temporal bone.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of cholesteatoma presents with vertigo. During the examination, pressing on his tragus induces vertigo. What does this finding most likely indicate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perilymph fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholesteatoma can erode the bony walls of the semicircular canals, leading to a perilymph fistula. Tragal pressure-induced vertigo strongly suggests a fistula in the lateral semicircular canal.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past week. She also reports severe headaches and swelling behind her ear. On examination, she has papilledema and edema on the posterior mastoid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sigmoid sinus thrombosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sigmoid sinus thrombosis is a complication of mastoiditis that presents with systemic infection, posterior mastoid swelling (Griesinger’s sign), papilledema, and increased intracranial pressure due to venous drainage obstruction.

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent male presents with recurrent profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction. On examination, a red and fleshy mass is observed in the nasal cavity. Imaging reveals broadening of the nasal bridge and a characteristic 'Holman-Miller sign'. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step?

options.label: C
options.text: CT scan of the paranasal sinuses

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate referral to a surgical oncologist

questions.correct_answer: C. CT scan of the paranasal sinuses
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CT scan of the paranasal sinuses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) requires initial imaging with a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the tumor before planning surgical intervention. Biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of significant bleeding.

questions.text: The image below shows a patient with unilateral swelling of the throat. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate referral to a surgical oncologist

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immediate incision and drainage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peritonsillar abscess requires immediate incision and drainage to prevent complications, followed by IV antibiotics to address the infection.

questions.text: The image below shows a patient with limited tongue movement and a visible band of tissue extending from the tongue to the floor of the mouth. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this condition in infants?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Impaired breastfeeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankyloglossia in infants most commonly results in impaired breastfeeding due to restricted tongue movement, which affects latching and swallowing.

questions.text: The image below shows a patient with a translucent, bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth. What is the most likely cause of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Trauma to the floor of the mouth

questions.correct_answer: C. Obstruction of sublingual gland duct
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Obstruction of sublingual gland duct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A ranula is caused by obstruction of the sublingual gland duct, leading to a translucent, bluish swelling in the floor of the mouth.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of pain and swelling in the submandibular area, particularly while eating meals. Which of the following salivary glands is most commonly affected by sialolithiasis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Submandibular gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The submandibular gland is the most common site for sialolithiasis due to its anatomical and physiological characteristics, resulting in recurrent submandibular pain and swelling during meals.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a gradually increasing firm swelling in the parotid region. Imaging reveals a well-defined mass in the tail of the parotid gland. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland, especially in younger patients presenting with a firm, painless swelling in the tail of the parotid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hearing loss after a traumatic injury to his ear. Audiometry reveals a 54 dB conductive hearing loss. Otoscopic examination shows an intact tympanic membrane. What is the most likely cause of his hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: Tympanic membrane perforation with ossicular dislocation

options.label: B
options.text: Ossicular dislocation with an intact tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. Ossicular dislocation with an intact tympanic membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ossicular dislocation with an intact tympanic membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ossicular dislocation with an intact tympanic membrane is the most likely cause of significant conductive hearing loss (~54 dB) following trauma. It disrupts sound conduction by creating a discontinuity in the ossicular chain.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents with a sudden onset of severe hearing loss. Audiometry reveals a conductive hearing loss of 54 dB. Given the levels of normal conversation, what is the patient's level of hearing loss equivalent to in everyday sounds?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Normal conversation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A conductive hearing loss of 54 dB corresponds to the inability to hear normal conversation (~60 dB), significantly affecting communication in everyday situations.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with hearing difficulty. On examination, the Rinne test is negative for the 256 Hz and 512 Hz tuning forks but positive for the 1024 Hz tuning fork. What is the approximate level of his hearing loss?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 30-45 dB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rinne test results can help estimate the degree of hearing loss based on frequency. Negative Rinne for 256 Hz and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz corresponds to moderate hearing loss of 30-45 dB.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man complains of gradual hearing loss over the past several years. His audiogram shows a down-sloping curve with sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) at higher frequencies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Presbycusis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presbycusis is the most common cause of gradual, bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in older adults, characterized by a down-sloping audiogram.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is undergoing a brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) test to evaluate her auditory pathway. Which of the following correctly lists the sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the cochlea to the auditory cortex?

options.label: A
options.text: Eighth nerve, olivary complex, cochlear nucleus, inferior colliculus, lateral lemniscus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, lateral lemniscus, olivary complex, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex

options.label: D
options.text: Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, lateral lemniscus, medial geniculate body, olivary complex, inferior colliculus, auditory cortex

questions.correct_answer: B. Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is:
  • ➤ Eighth nerve → Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex.
  • ➤ Eighth nerve → Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hoarseness of voice following thyroid surgery. Which nerve is most likely damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN)

options.label: B
options.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN)

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is commonly injured during thyroid surgery due to its anatomical proximity to the thyroid gland, causing hoarseness of voice due to paralysis of the intrinsic laryngeal muscles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male-to-female transgender patient seeks surgical intervention to feminize her voice. Which type of Isshiki thyroplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Type IV thyroplasty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type IV thyroplasty is the procedure of choice for voice feminization, as it lengthens the vocal cords and raises the pitch, ideal for male-to-female transgender patients or individuals with androphonia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with hoarseness of voice for the past three months. Laryngoscopy reveals the image shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vocal cord polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A vocal cord polyp is a unilateral lesion at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cord, commonly caused by phonotrauma and presenting with hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness. A lateral neck X-ray is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The steeple sign on an X-ray, along with barking cough, stridor, and hoarseness, is diagnostic of croup, a viral infection causing subglottic airway inflammation.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with noisy breathing and stridor that worsens when lying supine and improves when prone. The parents report that the infant has had these symptoms since birth. The endoscopic image shown was taken during evaluation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laryngomalacia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital stridor, characterized by an omega-shaped epiglottis, inspiratory stridor worsening in the supine position, and spontaneous resolution by 12–18 months.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with laryngeal cancer undergoes a surgical procedure that involves creating a permanent opening in his trachea. The device shown in the second image is provided to him post-operatively. What is the most likely surgical procedure he underwent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laryngectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngectomy involves removal of the larynx and creation of a permanent tracheostoma. Post-operatively, a tracheoesophageal prosthesis can be used for voice rehabilitation to enable speech.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is undergoing a tympanoplasty for chronic otitis media. Which focal length of the microscope lens is most appropriate for this ear surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 200 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ideal focal length of the microscope lens for ear surgeries like tympanoplasty is 200 mm, as it provides an optimal balance between magnification and working distance.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of nosebleeds. On examination, the bleeding point is located in the area marked in the image. Which area is most likely the source of the bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Little’s area

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Little’s area, located in the anterior nasal septum, is the most common site for recurrent anterior nosebleeds due to the rich vascular network of the Kiesselbach’s plexus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a chronic foul-smelling nasal discharge and nasal obstruction despite having a wide nasal cavity. She also reports a loss of smell. Examination reveals pale nasal mucosa and crusting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atrophic rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by a wide nasal cavity, foul-smelling discharge, pale mucosa, crusting, and anosmia, distinguishing it from other nasal conditions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompetent man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and thick nasal discharge. Examination reveals nasal polyposis and eosinophilic mucin without tissue invasion. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergillus fumigatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common organism causing allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS), a condition seen in immunocompetent individuals characterized by nasal polyposis and eosinophilic mucin without tissue invasion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with difficulty swallowing, bad breath, gurgling sounds on palpation of a left-sided neck swelling, and a confirmed diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum. Which anatomical structure is most commonly associated with the formation of Zenker's diverticulum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Killian's dehiscence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker's diverticulum forms at Killian's dehiscence, a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles, leading to symptoms like dysphagia, bad breath, and regurgitation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a characteristic facial appearance as shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this facial morphology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Obstructive sleep apnea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenoid facies, characterized by a dull, expressionless face with mouth breathing, is a classic feature of adenoid hypertrophy and obstructive sleep apnea in children.

questions.text: The image below shows the anatomical structure known as the bed of the tonsil. Which of the following conditions is commonly associated with inflammation or infection of this structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Peritonsillar abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bed of the tonsil is commonly involved in peritonsillar abscess, which arises as a complication of acute tonsillitis and causes pus accumulation in the peritonsillar space.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child complains of severe ear pain following tonsillectomy. Which anatomical structure is primarily responsible for this symptom?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Referred ear pain following tonsillectomy is due to irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve, which innervates both the tonsillar bed and the middle ear mucosa via Jacobson's nerve.
